As one of the original giants of the idle clicker genre, Clicker Heroes offers a pure, satisfying loop of clicking, upgrading heroes, and defeating ever-evolving monsters.

I‚Äôve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn‚Äôt fully expect. I don‚Äôt want to sound dramatic, but there‚Äôs something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together ‚Äî not in some perfect, polished ‚Äúadvertisement‚Äù way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just‚Ä¶ goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game ‚Äî the visuals, the sound, the pacing ‚Äî kind of blends into this feeling that you‚Äôre actually inside its world, even if you‚Äôre just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit clich√©, but it‚Äôs true. Sometimes it‚Äôs chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you‚Äôre just wandering around thinking ‚Äúok, what now?‚Äù but that‚Äôs honestly part of the charm. The game doesn‚Äôt try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought ‚Äúyeah, I‚Äôve seen this in other games,‚Äù but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It‚Äôs the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn‚Äôt have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again ‚Äî part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don‚Äôt punish you for not following some ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù path.

Overall, I‚Äôd say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn‚Äôt try too hard to impress in the first five minutes ‚Äî instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you‚Äôve been playing way longer than you planned. If you‚Äôre looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that‚Äôs just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would ‚Äî maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

Click. Click. Click.
Upgrade.
Walk away, grab a drink.
Come back. Numbers are bigger.
Click. Click. Click.
Repeat.

Basically a game about making numbers bigger so you can make other numbers bigger slightly faster, so that you can then go make more numbers bigger while you‚Äôre asleep.

It isn‚Äôt about fun in the traditional sense. But it‚Äôs about watching exponential growth until you realize you‚Äôve spent three weeks clicking pixels to finally be able to kill a giant slime with 78 quadrillion health.

10/10 would click again.

9/10 ‚Äî My mouse is begging for mercy.

I downloaded this game thinking, ‚ÄúHow fun could a clicking game be?‚Äù
Now it‚Äôs 3 AM, I‚Äôve ascended 27 times, and I get a dopamine hit every time a number goes up by 0.00001%.

At first, I was manually clicking monsters like some kind of caveman. Then I bought my first autoclicker and ascended into a higher plane of existence. My screen now plays itself while I stare blankly at the numbers like I‚Äôm watching the stock market of stupidity.

It‚Äôs the most fun I‚Äôve ever had doing absolutely nothing. It‚Äôs like a casino for people too tired to gamble.

Pros:

Big numbers go brrr 

Requires no skill, brain, or purpose

Can play while making dinner, sleeping, or questioning your life choices

Cons:

You will lose track of time, sanity, and possibly loved ones

The mouse click sound now haunts my dreams

I still don‚Äôt know why I‚Äôm having fun

Final Verdict:
I started playing out of boredom. I kept playing because‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt even know anymore.
Highly recommended if you‚Äôve ever wanted to achieve enlightenment through sheer apathy.
The game that taught me patience, addiction, and that I can literally watch numbers go up for hours and feel accomplished. 10/10 productivity at its finest.

Played for hundreds of hours to reach the goal of the game which is not to play it.

10/10

My In-Depth Review of Clicker Heroes

I‚Äôve spent a good amount of time playing Clicker Heroes, and I wanted to give a proper, honest review from my own experience. Even though it‚Äôs been around for years, it still holds up surprisingly well as one of the most addictive idle games out there.

What Clicker Heroes Is All About

At its core, Clicker Heroes is an incremental ‚Äúclicker‚Äù game where you start by clicking on monsters to kill them and earn gold. You use that gold to hire heroes who deal damage automatically, which means the game can keep running even when you‚Äôre not clicking. Over time, you unlock new heroes, abilities, ancients, and eventually a prestige system called Ascension, where you reset your progress to gain ‚ÄúHero Souls‚Äù and grow stronger for the next run.

It sounds simple, and it is ‚Äî but that‚Äôs exactly why it works.

What I Think the Game Does Really Well

1. Super Easy to Get Into
You can literally start playing in seconds. The feedback loop is instant: click, kill, earn gold, upgrade, repeat. It‚Äôs the kind of game that scratches that ‚Äúsatisfying number-go-up‚Äù itch immediately. Even if you leave it running in the background, it still feels like you‚Äôre making progress.

2. Surprisingly Deep Mechanics
At first, it‚Äôs just clicking. But as you get further, there‚Äôs a lot more strategy than you‚Äôd expect. You start learning which heroes scale better, how to optimize your damage per second (DPS), and how to balance idle vs. active play styles. Once the Ancients and gilding system unlock, it becomes more of a management game than a simple clicker.

3. Perfect for Playing Casually
This game is great for multitasking or just zoning out. You can play actively for a while, then leave it idle and come back to see how far you‚Äôve progressed. It‚Äôs also completely free, and you can enjoy the full experience without spending a penny.

4. A Great Example of an Idle Game Done Right
There are tons of idle games out there now, but Clicker Heroes really set the standard. It‚Äôs polished, easy to understand, and weirdly relaxing. The simple art style and upbeat music give it a kind of charm that never really gets old.

What I Don‚Äôt Like (and What Can Get Frustrating)

1. It Gets Repetitive After a While
There‚Äôs no escaping the fact that it‚Äôs the same loop over and over ‚Äî click, level up, reset, repeat. Once you‚Äôve hit Ascension a few times, the sense of progress slows down a lot. If you‚Äôre not into grinding or optimizing tiny details, it can start to feel stale.

2. The Mid-Game Wall
After a certain point, progression really slows down. You can hit a ‚Äúwall‚Äù where it takes ages to move forward unless you ascend again. It‚Äôs part of the design, but it can feel like the game is dragging just to stretch out playtime.

3. The Microtransactions (Though Not Terrible)
There‚Äôs an in-game currency called Rubies that you can buy with real money. To be fair, the game never forces you to spend, but it‚Äôs still there, and some people might find that annoying. Personally, I never needed to buy anything to enjoy it.

4. It‚Äôs Not for Everyone
If you like story-driven games, fast action, or complex mechanics, Clicker Heroes will probably bore you. It‚Äôs literally about watching numbers get bigger ‚Äî that‚Äôs the whole point. It‚Äôs weirdly addictive if you like that sort of thing, but mind-numbing if you don‚Äôt.

How It Holds Up Today (in 2025)

Even now, the game has a loyal player base and still gets decent attention on Steam and mobile. The graphics and interface are dated, but the core gameplay loop is timeless. With how many idle games have come and gone, Clicker Heroes remains one of the few that still feels rewarding.

That said, the lack of major new updates makes it feel a bit frozen in time. It‚Äôs not a live-service game with constant events or new content ‚Äî it‚Äôs just the same loop that‚Äôs been perfected over years.

My Final Verdict

For what it is, Clicker Heroes is a fantastic idle game. It‚Äôs easy to play, oddly satisfying, and has enough layers to keep you coming back. It‚Äôs not deep in the traditional gaming sense, but it nails that feeling of endless progress.

If I had to rate it:
‚≠ê 8/10 ‚Äî great fun if you‚Äôre into incremental games, but repetitive if you‚Äôre not.

Pros:
‚úÖ Addictive and rewarding gameplay loop
‚úÖ Lots of hidden depth and strategy
‚úÖ Free to play, no paywall
‚úÖ Relaxing and simple

Cons:
‚ùå Can feel grindy and repetitive
‚ùå Progress slows down over time
‚ùå Minimal visual or gameplay variety

Overall:
Clicker Heroes is one of those games that you don‚Äôt play for the story or action ‚Äî you play it for that satisfying sense of progression. It‚Äôs the perfect ‚Äúbackground game,‚Äù something to click while watching YouTube or doing something else. Even after all these years, it still stands as one of the best examples of how to make an idle game both fun and addictive.

Clicker Heroes is basically finger cardio for the financially ambitious. You start off mildly curious, clicking a slime, and suddenly you‚Äôre obsessively calculating quadrillions of damage per second while your mouse quietly files for divorce. Heroes explode into gold, numbers skyrocket, and somehow hiring a hero named King Midas feels morally correct despite the chaos. It‚Äôs addictive, ridiculous, and perfect for anyone who wants to feel powerful without doing literally anything. 10/10, my fingers hurt but my ego is huge.

This game brings back memories when I was on my xbox, this game was nice and enjoyable to just watch and let it progress over time. I will always love any idle game that actually has a good reason to play.
Has a lot of cloud sync problems. Apart from that its a long play game that you can idle most of the way to the end unlike most clicker games.

A surprisingly engaging idle game! Watching numbers go up is oddly satisfying, and while it's repetitive, simple system is easy to get into. A good choice if you're looking for something to play passively while doing other things.
one of the best idle/clicker games i've played. scales really nicely, has forgiving gameplay, and feels much more balanced than other similar games.

negative.review:
Surprisingly shallow, even for its time.
The process, while may seem addicting at first, never shows anything interesting or rewarding.
Idle game. It's a good one, but it's an idle game. Don't make the mistake I did.

I've played some good and fun clicker games. This wasn't one of them. In a word: BORING. Less than five minutes in and I uninstalled it and removed it from my account because I couldn't imagine wasting another minute of my time on it.

The nostalgia is great, but past a certain point there's nothing new of interest, turning the game into a mindless slog to get through.
Certainly not the worst clicker game out there though!
35 clicks a second achievement is broke im literally using an a macro and i tested it and its coming up as 215 clicks a second but on this game its only recognising 30 out of the 35

I refused to stop until I 100% it.
I've never regretted starting something as much as I have this game.

It is an engine that runs on time and focus, and you do not have enough to feed it.
Fun until you realize that the game has little to no depth or creativity in it, and that you'll just be ascending and transcending in the same way over and over again to no end.

The main problem with this incremental game is that the gameplay loop, which involves many repeated ascensions, always requires waiting around 2 hours to re-climb the weak, low-level floors. Your progression rate is HARD-CAPPED to 2/2 enemies per floor, with insta-kill DPS, with no way to skip or hasten these lower levels. The result is most of the time in this game is waiting to get back to a level where you can make meaningful progression. Very boring, would not recommend.

I would not recommend this game has the maker only wants your money from buying gems. I have 5 heroes  and all but 1 is dead. The last one died an will cost over 9,000,000 gems to get back. He was the one I was using to get the rest back.

Having played this game a fair bit I think it's lacking substance. There's nothing keeping my attention.

Game is good for being a clicker game. No overly complex designs. Just the standard level up characters, god bonuses, prestige(ascend), and full reset prestige(transcend).  You can earn the p2w currency by playing the game and just clicking the goldfish that appears every few minutes. Another way of getting the currency is using mercenaries  that may have ruby missions that can be time skipped. The last way to get rubies is to participate in guild battles. you can get a couple hundred a day or more by fighting AND killing the guild boss. So whether you find an active guild( like Palworld) or you create a solo guild, you can get rubies if you lock the boss level within the health range that you and your guild can one shot it. 

If you are ever going to use a time skip, make sure to look at your mercenaries before and after to mitigate the rubies being spent. 

My main complaint about this game and its nothing new to the developers or the community..... memory leak. If you plan to play this game, do not leave it alone without monitoring your pc every so often. I left the game minimized and it went from 500MB of ram (excessive for a game that is a quarter of that size) to 24 gb of ram in an 8 hour period. I know clicker heroes 2 was taken off the steam market place but respectfully, this game should also be taken off because a game should not be able to reach the ram size that is 200 times the actual game size. It would be like CoD requiring you to have 20TB of RAM... rediculous.

Probably one of the buggiest games i've ever played. Constantly has issues with hero's stopping their attacks, meaning that you'll have to restart your game every 10mins if you're being generous. Just don't get it

its a fine game.
but it lacks offline progress that much that most of the players would probably try to download save file from the internet.
Don't Waste your time!  ( Go play something better you really like )

The main problem with this incremental game is that the gameplay loop, which involves many repeated ascensions, always requires waiting around 2 hours to re-climb the weak, low-level floors. Your progression rate is HARD-CAPPED to 2/2 enemies per floor, with insta-kill DPS, with no way to skip or hasten these lower levels. The result is most of the time in this game is waiting to get back to a level where you can make meaningful progression. Very boring, would not recommend.

Upgrading ancients is not automated. That's the crucial defection of this game.

Others are fine.
Not so greedy, and satisfying background idle game

I would not recommend this game has the maker only wants your money from buying gems. I have 5 heroes  and all but 1 is dead. The last one died an will cost over 9,000,000 gems to get back. He was the one I was using to get the rest back.

You click, you upgrade, you click again and somewhere between the tenth and thousandth click, you realize your brain has gone on vacation without you. It‚Äôs less idle fun and more digital hypnosis, designed to make you mistake time loss for accomplishment.
Just spend 5 euros for Cookie Clicker; this game sucks.
It's not a bad game; but in what world would this ever be good enough to recommend?
Having played this game a fair bit I think it's lacking substance. There's nothing keeping my attention.
i like it but it gets very repetetive quick, try revo idle instead
save seems fucked. have to do manual saving every time. fuck is wrong with this
i give a dislike because i forgot the game for a year before playing it again
Awful progression for an idle game
only recommend if they make it so i can use a controller instead.
its okey, fun for awhile :)
No gameplay no story
takes so long

The graphics are nothing special at all...
The game itself is boring but addictive, which is bad in this case, as far as I'm concerned.
There are definitely better options out there.
Yeah, and watch how much DLC costs!

Game is good for being a clicker game. No overly complex designs. Just the standard level up characters, god bonuses, prestige(ascend), and full reset prestige(transcend).  You can earn the p2w currency by playing the game and just clicking the goldfish that appears every few minutes. Another way of getting the currency is using mercenaries  that may have ruby missions that can be time skipped. The last way to get rubies is to participate in guild battles. you can get a couple hundred a day or more by fighting AND killing the guild boss. So whether you find an active guild( like Palworld) or you create a solo guild, you can get rubies if you lock the boss level within the health range that you and your guild can one shot it. 

If you are ever going to use a time skip, make sure to look at your mercenaries before and after to mitigate the rubies being spent. 

My main complaint about this game and its nothing new to the developers or the community..... memory leak. If you plan to play this game, do not leave it alone without monitoring your pc every so often. I left the game minimized and it went from 500MB of ram (excessive for a game that is a quarter of that size) to 24 gb of ram in an 8 hour period. I know clicker heroes 2 was taken off the steam market place but respectfully, this game should also be taken off because a game should not be able to reach the ram size that is 200 times the actual game size. It would be like CoD requiring you to have 20TB of RAM... rediculous.

Surprisingly shallow, even for its time.
The process, while may seem addicting at first, never shows anything interesting or rewarding.

Pretty fun, but you hit a wall around level 150 where you have to start getting in the weeds with the meta and it starts to really push you towards premium currency. I wouldn't mind if the game itself had a personality, but it's just kinda bland and the theming is schizophrenic and uninspired.
Idle game. It's a good one, but it's an idle game. Don't make the mistake I did.

I've played some good and fun clicker games. This wasn't one of them. In a word: BORING. Less than five minutes in and I uninstalled it and removed it from my account because I couldn't imagine wasting another minute of my time on it.

The nostalgia is great, but past a certain point there's nothing new of interest, turning the game into a mindless slog to get through.
Certainly not the worst clicker game out there though!
35 clicks a second achievement is broke im literally using an a macro and i tested it and its coming up as 215 clicks a second but on this game its only recognising 30 out of the 35

I refused to stop until I 100% it.
I've never regretted starting something as much as I have this game.
